Description: Rim sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery heavy chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; alternating lotus flowers and with palmettes in added white outline with added red centres; exterior: alternating red and black tongues between dilute lines below rim, above zigzag band between dilute lines; below, part of pendant roundel as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: The sherd joins UCL 751 and belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1888,0601.465.a, 1888,0601.465.c, 1888,0601.465.d, 1888,0601.465.e, London UCL 393, Paris E8056 bis.22 and Boston 88.830. The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1965,0930.338. Lemos describes the sherd as coming from a mediocre but big chalice belonging to the Group of Elaborate Animal Chalices. Chalices that fall into this group are usually large and heavy-walled and are also known as chalice-kraters. Chalices in this group also display elaborate compositions that include polychromy and delicately painted figures (Lemos 1991, 90-1).
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 90, p. 263, no. 552)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1563) (phase 2)
